title: Rath Yatra
hero_image_alt: Devotees pulling the chariot of Lord Jagannath
short_description: The giant Chariot Festival of Puri, where millions pull the massive wooden chariots of Lord Jagannath.
long_description:
The Rath Yatra in Puri, Odisha, is one of the oldest and most spectacular processions in the world. It involves Lord Jagannath (Lord of the Universe), his brother Balabhadra, and sister Subhadra stepping out of their temple to visit their aunt's house, the Gundicha Temple. This journey is made on three colossal wooden chariots (Raths), the main one being 45 feet tall. 

What makes this unique is that typically, non-Hindus are not allowed inside the Jagannath Temple. The Rath Yatra is the only time the deities come out to give darshan (blessings) to everyone, regardless of caste or creed. Pulling the thick ropes of the chariot is considered an act of great merit. The energy is frantic and devotional, with shouts of 'Jai Jagannath' rising above the sound of gongs and cymbals.
significance: Symbolizes the journey of the Lord to meet his devotees.
key_rituals: Chhera Pahanra: The King of Puri sweeps the chariot floor with a golden broom, symbolizing humility.
Pahandi: The rhythmic swaying movement of deities as they are carried to chariots.
Chariot Pulling: Millions of devotees pulling the ropes.
Bahuda Yatra: The return journey after 9 days.

practical_info.dress_tips: Cotton clothing. It is extremely hot and humid in Odisha during June/July.
practical_info.safety_tips: Suffocation is a risk in the densest crowds locally. Watch from rooftops or balconies if possible.
practical_info.accessibility_notes: Impossible for wheelchairs on the street level.

faqs.a: In the chaos, people try, but security is tight. Pulling the rope is the main goal.
